choices.C: AWS login ID to login to the console
choices.D: Access key and secret access key

discussion.content:
C is the correct answer.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/creating-an-ami-instance-store.html#bundle-ami-prerequisites
What is difference between AWS login ID & AWS account ID?

comments.content: The certificate is only required to create an instance-backed AMI (as opposed to an EBS-backed AMI). You can have AWS create an X. 509 certificate and private key that you can download, or you can upload your own certificate by using the Security Credentials page.
Why C is incorrect? Could you please explain?

discussion.content: B. X.509 certificate and private key

questions.question_text: A user has launched an EC2 instance from an instance store backed AMI. The infrastructure team wants to create an AMI from the running instance. Which of the below mentioned credentials is not required while creating the AMI?

discussion.content: D. ELB will not modify the headers
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing/latest/classic/elb-listener-config.html

comments.content:
to make more clear :
A. It is not possible to have the SSL listener both at ELB and back-end instances
 No. ELB allows frontend and backend listeners.
 
B. ELB will modify headers to add requestor details
 Yes. When Proxy is placed only. Here the question not mentioned about the proxy.

C. ELB will intercept the request to add the cookie details if sticky session is enabled.
 HTTP/HTTPs will accept sticky sessions, SSL Not.
D. ELB will not modify the headers
 Here the question does not mention that Proxy protocol. Hence this is the right answer.
 But if ELB Used Proxy and Different protocols from backend and frontend then, it should modify the headers.

questions.answer_description:
When the user has configured Transmission Control Protocol (TCP. or Secure Sockets Layer (SSL. for both front-end and back-end connections of the Elastic
Load Balancer, the load balancer forwards the request to the back-end instances without modifying the request headers unless the proxy header is enabled. SSL does not support sticky sessions. If the user has enabled a proxy protocol it adds the source and destination IP to the header.

choices.A: It is not possible to have the SSL listener both at ELB and back-end instances
choices.D: ELB will not modify the headers
choices.C: ELB will intercept the request to add the cookie details if sticky session is enabled
choices.B: ELB will modify headers to add requestor details

questions.question_text: A user has configured an SSL listener at ELB as well as on the back-end instances. Which of the below mentioned statements helps the user understand ELB traffic handling with respect to the SSL listener?

A user has created a Cloudformation stack. The stack creates AWS services, such as EC2 instances, ELB, AutoScaling, and RDS. While creating the stack it created EC2, ELB and AutoScaling but failed to create RDS. What will Cloudformation do in this scenario?

choices.B: It will warn the user about the error and ask the user to manually create RDS
choices.D: It will wait for the user's input about the error and correct the mistake after the input
choices.C: Rollback all the changes and terminate all the created services
choices.A: Cloudformation can never throw an error after launching a few services since it verifies all the steps before launching

discussion.content: C seems like the right answer. I took the DVA exam a few weeks back. Seems along the lines of the questions on that exam.
C. Rollback all the changes and terminate all the created services

questions.answer_description:
AWS Cloudformation is an application management tool which provides application modelling, deployment, configuration, management and related activities. The
AWS Cloudformation stack is a collection of AWS resources which are created and managed as a single unit when AWS CloudFormation instantiates a template.
If any of the services fails to launch, Cloudformation will rollback all the changes and terminate or delete all the created services.

questions.question_text: A user is trying to launch an EBS backed EC2 instance under free usage. The user wants to achieve encryption of the EBS volume. How can the user encrypt the data at rest?

choices.B: The user cannot use EBS encryption and has to encrypt the data manually or using a third party tool
choices.A: Use AWS EBS encryption to encrypt the data at rest
choices.C: The user has to select the encryption enabled flag while launching the EC2 instance
choices.D: Encryption of volume is not available as a part of the free usage tier

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/prescriptive-guidance/latest/patterns/automatically-encrypt-existing-and-new-amazon-ebs-volumes.html

Selected Answer: A
Encryption is allowed on micro instances

Correct Answer: C
The flag for encryption must be enabled first. It's available for the free usage tier .
Answer is C.

Answer: A.
Small glimse
Supported instance types
Amazon EBS encryption is available on the instance types listed below. You can attach both encrypted and unencrypted volumes to these instance types simultaneously.
General purpose: A1, M3, M4, M5, M5a, M5ad, M5d, M5dn, M5n, M6g, T2, T3, and T3a



Earlier it was not allowed in free tier, so the answer was B.
Answer is A.
I would think the answer should be C

No one check what the question is asked “free tier”, so only micro instances are eligible on free tire. Other instances can be use but not part of the free tier.

So answer is B. Need to use third party software.
Could anyone please confirm if we can encrypt EBS Volumes once they are already created?
Answer is "C"

Answer is C. It says in the beginning "A user is trying to launch..." Hence, when launching an EC2, the user can select the option to encrypt the drive. 

If the question said something like " A user is trying the encrypt the EBS volumes on one of his EBS drives, attached to an EC2 instance". (A) would have been a possibility, however, remember you can't just encrypt an unencrypted EBS Volume on the fly like that. Just FYI
C. The user has to select the encryption enabled flag while launching the EC2 instance

"It is not supported with a micro instance. " It is not true.
You can do it with a micro.

Bad Question > I dont undestand this question. whether they want to encrypt data at rest after launching or before launching..? Question says ..trying to launch that means not launched yet. But end of the sentence says data at rest..

comments.content: I tested in free tier. Encryption of volume is available as a part of the free usage tie
yeah you are right, i also tried and want to say that bulshit answer is C

discussion.content: The user has to select the encryption enabled flag while volume section. They triggered here.

questions.answer_description: AWS EBS supports encryption of the volume while creating new volumes. It supports encryption of the data at rest, the I/O as well as all the snapshots of the EBS volume. The EBS supports encryption for the selected instance type and the newer generation instances, such as m3, c3, cr1, r3, g2. It is not supported with a micro instance.

choices.D: It will not allow to delete the VPC since it has a running NAT instance
choices.C: It will terminate the VPC along with all the instances launched by the wizard

It is D.
actually, when we select the "VPC with Public and Private Subnets" configuration through the VPC Wizard, it automatically creates also a Nat gateway in the public subnet to us. Then if we want to delete the VPC we need to firt delete the nat gateway.

Correct Answer: D
 If these subnets are created with Wizard, AWS will create a NAT instance with an elastic IP. If the user is trying to delete the VPC it will not allow as the NAT instance is still running.

This question doesn't even reference a nat instance
D. It will not allow to delete the VPC since it has a running NAT instance
I think Ans D Explanation should refer NAT Gateway Instead of Nat Instance, anyway EIP required.

questions.question_text:
A user has created a VPC with public and private subnets using the VPC wizard. The user has not launched any instance manually and is trying to delete the
VPC. What will happen in this scenario?
questions.answer_description: A Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) is a virtual network dedicated to the user's AWS account. A user can create a subnet with VPC and launch instances inside that subnet. If the user has created a public private subnet, the instances in the public subnet can receive inbound traffic directly from the Internet, whereas the instances in the private subnet cannot. If these subnets are created with Wizard, AWS will create a NAT instance with an elastic IP. If the user is trying to delete the VPC it will not allow as the NAT instance is still running.
